Com desemprego recorde, aumentam golpes e falsas ofertas de trabalho

O nï¿½mero recorde de 12,7 milhï¿½es de desempregados no Brasil â€“ o maior desde 2012 - tem deixado os trabalhadores e trabalhadoras mais vulnerï¿½veis a golpes e exploraï¿½ï¿½es.

Por Rosaly Rocha para Portal CUT

Tem de tudo na praï¿½a, desde anï¿½ncios que oferecem  vagas inexistentes, com bons salï¿½rios e benefï¿½cios; a empresas que, em troca da vaga, cobram de R$ 2 mil a R$ 8 mil por ano dos trabalhadores para que comprem roupas da lojas que serï¿½o usadas como uniformes. Tem tambï¿½m empresas que cobram por cursos e treinamentos e depois dizem nï¿½o ter emprego nenhum.

Isso ï¿½ crime. A procuradora Eliane Lucina, do Ministï¿½rio Pï¿½blico do Trabalho de Sï¿½o Paulo (MPT-SP), orienta os trabalhadores e trabalhadoras a procurarem o sindicato de suas categorias sempre que desconfiarem ou forem vï¿½timas de golpes e fraudes.

Segundo ela, a fraude, na maioria das vezes, ï¿½ feita antes do contrato de trabalho ser assinado e os sindicatos estï¿½o habilitados a fazer a denï¿½ncia no MPT.

Os golpistas estï¿½o sujeitos a dois processos: um de ordem civil e outro, penal. â€œO civil ï¿½ uma aï¿½ï¿½o pï¿½blica aberta pelo MPT por delito trabalhista. De ordem penal, os envolvidos podem ser processados criminalmente por estelionato, vantagem ilï¿½cita, falsidade ideolï¿½gica e fraude na Justiï¿½a comumï¿½.

O MPT-SP nï¿½o tem pesquisas com dados mais concretos, mas pelas denï¿½ncias que o ï¿½rgï¿½o tem recebido, a procuradora Eliane Lucina diz que â€œo nï¿½mero de golpes a trabalhadores realmente vem aumentando com o desempregoï¿½.

E os exemplos de exploraï¿½ï¿½o e golpes se multiplicam em todo paï¿½s. Em Sï¿½o Paulo, a procuradora estï¿½ trabalhando em uma denï¿½ncia de uma vendedora de uma grande rede de lojas, que foi obrigada a comprar a nova coleï¿½ï¿½o de roupas da prï¿½pria loja para comeï¿½ar a trabalhar. Ela sï¿½ trabalhou um mï¿½s, na ï¿½poca do Natal, e gastou cerca de R$ 2 mil na compra de roupas que nï¿½o precisava, conta Eliane Lucina.

â€œPara piorar, a loja nï¿½o desconta o valor no contracheque, obriga seus funcionï¿½rios a pagarem com o prï¿½prio cartï¿½o de crï¿½ditoï¿½, diz a procuradora, que abriu sindicï¿½ncia contra a rede de lojas, cujo nome sï¿½ poderï¿½ revelar quando a empresa for notificada.

Para os homens que trabalham na mesma loja, a rede exige camisa social, mais cara que as camisas polos.  â€œSï¿½o quatro coleï¿½ï¿½es ao ano. Se pegar como exemplo os R$ 2 mil em compras de uma sï¿½ coleï¿½ï¿½o, os funcionï¿½rios chegam a gastar R$ 8 mil ao ano. Um peso muito grande no orï¿½amentoï¿½, diz a procuradora.

Segundo ela, um exemplo recente de golpe aconteceu em Brasï¿½lia. Cada trabalhador pagou R$ 50 por uma vaga  numa empresa que nï¿½o existia.

Outro golpe comum ï¿½ quando a empresa oferece sociedade, mas na verdade o trabalhador estï¿½ sendo contratado como PJ â€“ pessoa jurï¿½dica.

â€œTive um caso contra uma Clï¿½nica de Olhos que obrigou uma enfermeira a abrir uma empresa. Depois, ela descobriu que a Clï¿½nica colocou todos os funcionï¿½rios registrados na sua empresa. No caso, ela foi â€˜laranjaâ€™ sem prï¿½vio conhecimentoï¿½, contou a procuradora Eliane Lucina.

- Empresas que fazem treinamento prï¿½vio com vendas. O trabalhador vende os produtos durante uma semana e ao final nï¿½o ï¿½ contratado. Trabalhou de graï¿½a nesse perï¿½odo;

- Empresas que oferecem baixos salï¿½rios e altas comissï¿½es, mas as metas sï¿½o inatingï¿½veis e o trabalhador nunca consegue receber sua comissï¿½o. Quando a meta ï¿½ atingida, o trabalhador descobre que nï¿½o tem nenhum documento escrito e a empresa aumenta a meta;

- Agï¿½ncias de emprego cobram taxas para encaminhamento de vagas;

- Vagas em troca de cursos. Empresas oferecem vagas desde que o trabalhador faï¿½a um curso pago para conseguir o emprego. Depois do curso, ele descobre que a vaga nï¿½o existe.

O trabalhador que quiser fazer uma denï¿½ncia deve entrar no site do Ministï¿½rio Pï¿½blico:  www.mpt.mp.br  e escolher o estado onde o golpe estï¿½ ocorrendo.

Em Sï¿½o Paulo a denï¿½ncia pode ser feita no MPT-SP pelo site  www.prt2.mpt.mp.br

Em caso de denï¿½ncia de trabalho infantil e escravo ligue: 0800111616

content:
(TNS) Columbus, Ohio, expects to finish outfitting police officers with body cameras this summer, six months ahead of schedule.

More than 850 officers already are wearing the cameras, which the city began purchasing in late 2016, and a total of about 1,300 should begin using them by the end of June.

Originally, officials expected the rollout to run through the end of 2018. But implementation "has proceeded very smoothly," Bob Stewart, assistant director in the Department of Public Safety, told Columbus City Council members last week.

Columbus selected WatchGuard Video of Allen, Texas, as its vendor for 1,575 body cameras and accessories in December 2016 after Mayor Andrew J. Ginther promised during his 2015 campaign that he would bring the technology to the Division of Police.

"From the earliest days of his administration, Mayor Ginther has made the implementation of body-worn cameras a top priority because they are an important tool to enhance public safety," said Robin Davis, Ginther's spokeswoman.

The cost of the rollout at that time was expected to be about $9.1 million over five years, including the equipment, training, server space to store video and licensing fees. About $3.6 million was for cameras and $4.1 million for data storage.

So far, the city is ahead of schedule and under budget, said George Speaks, assistant director of public safety.

Last year, the city spent about $4.5 million on body-camera implementation, including about $1.6 million for the cameras and $1.3 million for storage. Running fiber-optic cable to police substations through which officers can upload video was cheaper than expected, costing about $706,000, said Speaks, the department's chief architect for the body-camera program.

"I think the implementation has gone very well," he said. "Part of that is all of the work that we did at looking where cities failed their implementation."

Speaks said the Columbus Police Training Academy also has been able to expedite the training of officers to operate the cameras by using an instructional video, which is getting the cameras to officers faster.

The city initially equipped about a dozen police officers with the cameras. Bike and traffic patrol officers were the first to get them, followed by new police recruits.

As of Tuesday, 869 officers had body cameras, Speaks said.

Last year, the city budgeted to hire seven people to deal with body-camera footage. They included people to deal with records requests to police and additional staff in the city attorney's office to handle a new bank of evidence.

The 2017 budget anticipated the seven workers to have salaries totaling about $326,000.

City Attorney Zach Klein said his office has hired only two of the four workers originally anticipated. Those two have been working on acquiring footage, searching hours-long videos for specific interactions and cutting down the footage for prosecutors, he said. With more cameras coming online, he said, he is working with the administration to determine whether additional staffing is needed.

The camera footage is showing the "unvarnished truth" of what happens in police interactions, Klein said.

"It is a wise investment because it protects the community and police, and having sunshine on this process and police interactions is good for all parties involved," he said.

Speaks said the city is evaluating whether the staff it has hired is sufficient to deal with the additional workload the cameras create. Those jobs could be affected by proposed rules for when body-camera video will be released to the public, which is pending in the legislature.

A bill introduced in November is still in committee, according to the Legislative Service Commission.

Implementing the cameras has mostly been smooth, but some minor problems have cropped up, said Jason Pappas, president of the Fraternal Order of Police Capital City Lodge No. 9. For example, lights on some cameras wouldn't turn off when officers were supposed to use them in "stealth mode," such as during a SWAT situation, he said.

Police officers, though, are growing accustomed to the new technology, Pappas said.
title: Columbus, Ohioâ€™s Body Camera Deployment Ahead of Schedule

content:
You shouldn't have to do this. You shouldn't have to wade through complicated privacy settings in order to ensure that the companies with which you've entrusted your personal information are making reasonable, legal efforts to protect it. But Facebook has allowed third parties to violate user privacy on an unprecedented scale, and, while legislators and regulators scramble to understand the implications and put limits in place, users are left with the responsibility to make sure their profiles are properly configured.

Over the weekend, it became clear that Cambridge Analytica, a data analytics company, got access to more than 50 million Facebook users' data in 2014. The data was overwhelmingly collected, shared, and stored without user consent. The scale of this violation of user privacy reflects how Facebook's terms of service and API were structured at the time. Make no mistake: this was not a data breach. This was exactly how Facebook's infrastructure was designed to work.

In addition to raising questions about Facebook's role in the 2016 presidential election, this news is a reminder of the inevitable privacy risks that users face when their personal information is captured, analyzed, indefinitely stored, and shared by a constellation of data brokers, marketers, and social media companies.

Tech companies can and should do more to protect users, including giving users far more control over what data is collected and how that data is used. That starts with meaningful transparency and allowing truly independent researchersâ€”with no bottom line or corporate interestâ€”access to work with, black-box test, and audit their systems. Finally, users need to be able to leave when a platform isnâ€™t serving them â€” and take their data with them when they do.

Of course, you could choose to leave Facebook entirely, but for many that is not a viable solution. For now, if you'd like keep your data from going through Facebook's API, you can take control of your privacy settings. Keep in mind that this disables ALL platform apps (like Farmville, Twitter, or Instagram) and you will not be able to log into sites using your Facebook login.

Log into Facebook and visit theÂ App SettingsÂ page (or go there manually via the SettingsÂ Menu > AppsÂ ).

From there, click the "Edit" button under "Apps, Websites and Plugins." Click "Disable Platform."

If disabling platform entirely is too much, there is another setting that can help: limiting the personal information accessible by apps that others use. By default, other people who can see your info can bring it with them when they use apps, and your info becomes available to those apps. You can limit this as follows.

From the same page, click "Edit" under "Apps Others Use." Then uncheck the types of information that you don't want others' apps to be able to access. For most people reading this post, that will mean unchecking every category.
title: How To Change Your Facebook Settings To Opt Out of Platform API Sharing

content:
An overhaul of Capitol Hillâ€™s workplace misconduct system is in jeopardy and likely wonâ€™t be attached to a government spending bill this week, diminishing the likelihood of reform before the midterm elections, according to Politico.

Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY), who introduced the bipartisan Congressional Harassment Reform Act last December, said on Monday that House and Senate leadership â€œstrippedâ€ provisions from the language from the spending bill at the eleventh hour.

â€œI am appalled that House and Senate leadership removed provisions from the omnibus bill at the last minute that would have finally brought accountability and transparency to Congressâ€™s sexual harassment reporting process,â€ said Gillibrand in a statement released Monday.

Among its provisions, the act requires that members of Congress personally pay for sexual harassment settlements when they are found liable. Currently, lawmakers can tap taxpayer funds to settle with victims. Also, unless the victim opts for privacy, under the act, settlements would automatically be made public, thus lifting the veil of secrecy around the process.

The provisions, noted Gillibrand, passed unanimously in the House, and the act has broad support in the Senate.

â€œIt begs the question: Who are they trying to protect? I canâ€™t think of any legitimate reason to remove this language other than to protect members of Congress over taxpayers and congressional employees,â€ said Gillibrand, who on Monday called on the Senate leadership to bring the legislation to the floor for an immediate vote.

Congress is facing a Friday midnight deadline to approve its spending bill. And on Monday, Politico cited sources who reported that the harassment measure was unlikely to get attached to the spending bill, a shift that â€œjeopardizesâ€ the chances that the bill would move forward and onto President Trumpâ€™s desk for a signature.

However, a spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY), disputed Gillibrandâ€™s account that provisions of the act were on track to be included in the spending bill, according to Politico.

â€œThe government funding bill is still being developed, so I donâ€™t have any update on the final bill,â€Â  spokesman Don Stewart told PoliticoÂ in an email. â€œAnd while this important issue is being discussed, at no time was language from Sen. Gillibrandâ€™s bill adopted to the legislation and/or stripped.â€

Gillibrand has been one of the most outspoken critics of Capitol Hillâ€™s sexual harassment complaint process, calling the system â€œbrokenâ€ and urging her colleagues to take action.

â€œCongress should never be able to play by their own set of rules or ever be above the law,â€ Gillibrand told CNN last November.

Others have called the system antiquated. For example, accusers must first agree to counseling and mediation before they may file a lawsuit, according to the Washington Post.

Recently, reporters have uncovered several cases where members of Congress used taxpayer money to settle sexual harassment complaints filed by former staff members

Last month, in urging Senate leadership to take action on her bill, Gillibrand reminded her colleagues that an overhaul of the system is urgent. â€œThe more time that goes by without addressing this broken system, the more people suffer,â€ Gillibrand wrote in a letter to McConnell and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY).
title: Congress quietly preserves ability to pay sexual harassment settlements with taxpayer money

O assunto se espalhou atravÃ©s das redes sociais na segunda quinzena marÃ§o de 2018, poucos dias apÃ³s o assassinato da vereadora â€“ ocorrido no centro do Rio de Janeiro. De acordo com o texto, Marielle Franco teria engravidado do traficante Marcinho VP, aos 16 anos de idade, alÃ©m de ter sido eleita pelo Comando Vermelho e ter exonerado seis de seus funcionÃ¡rios recentemente.

A ideia da publicaÃ§Ã£o que foi disseminada na web Ã© a de mostrar que a vereadora teria vÃ¡rios motivos para ser morta por criminosos (e nÃ£o pela PolÃ­cia)! Ou seja, a vÃ­tima teria sido a culpada pela sua prÃ³pria morteâ€¦

SerÃ¡ que essas informaÃ§Ãµes sÃ£o reais?

Marielle Franco tinha 38 anos de idade quando foi assassinada no Rio de Janeiro, em 2018. Defensora dos direitos humanos, a vereadora vinha denunciando abusos por parte da PolÃ­cia Militar nas comunidades.

NÃ£o encontramos nada que confirme (e nem que desminta) que a mulher era usuÃ¡ria de maconha (detalhe esse que, se fosse verdade ou nÃ£o, nÃ£o justificaria a sua morte).

Marielle teve uma filha, Luyara, quando tinha 19 anos (e nÃ£o 16 como espalharam por aÃ­).

NÃ£o hÃ¡ nenhuma informaÃ§Ã£o sobre algum casamento da falecida em nenhuma reportagem a respeito dela. O Wikipedia nÃ£o cita nenhum cÃ´njugeÂ (seja ele atual ou ex).

O fato Ã© que uma busca por â€œMarcinho VPâ€ retornam duas respostas. HÃ¡ pelo menos dois traficantes conhecidos com oâ€Marcinho VPâ€:

* , traficante de drogas que atua no Complexo do AlemÃ£o

O primeiro, morreu em 2003, aos 33 anos de idade, no presÃ­dio Bangu3 onde estava preso desde 2000. Nessa Ã©poca, Marielle Franco tinha 19 anos e morava no Complexo da MarÃ©. JÃ¡ o traficante, antes de ser preso, comandava a favela Santa Marta â€“ que fica a cerca de 20 km de distÃ¢ncia da casa da moÃ§a. Parece ser pouco provÃ¡vel que eles foram casados nessa Ã©poca, dada a distÃ¢ncia entre eles e a total falta de provas desse enlace.

No caso do outro â€œMarcinho VPâ€ (o traficante do Complexo do AlemÃ£o), a possibilidade dele ter se casado com a vereadora tambÃ©m Ã© mÃ­nima, visto que ele estÃ¡ preso desde 1997 e â€“ igualmente como ocorreu no caso do Marcinho da favela Santa Marta â€“ nÃ£o hÃ¡ nenhuma prova de que ele tenha se casado com a vÃ­tima!

Outra informaÃ§Ã£o espalhada pela web afirma que a vereadora teria sido eleita pelo Comando Vermelho. No entanto, uma busca por fontes a respeito e apenas encontramos aqueles mesmos sites de sempre que jÃ¡ conhecemos por espalhar notÃ­cias falsas.

Buscando atravÃ©s de uma fonte confiÃ¡vel â€“ no caso, o site do Tribunal Regional Eleitoral do Rio de Janeiro â€“ podemos perceber que Marielle Franco foi a quinta mais votada da cidade, com maiores quantidades de votos vindos de bairros como Leblon, Copacabana e Ipanema. Como podemos ver nesse recorte de um infogrÃ¡fico do portal G1 abaixo, as comunidades onde o Comando Vermelho atua sequer aparecem no ranking:

Se a vereadora tivesse sido eleita mesmo graÃ§as ao Comando Vermelho, certamente as comunidades comandadas por essa facÃ§Ã£o teriam maior representatividade na eleiÃ§Ã£o de Marielle.

Esse rumor se espalhou de tal maneira que atÃ© pessoas pÃºblicas caÃ­ram nessa, como a desembargadora do TJ-RJ MarÃ­lia Castro Neves, que publicou em sua conta no Facebook acusaÃ§Ãµes contra a entÃ£o recÃ©m-assassinada Marielle Franco:

Em entrevista Ã  jornalista MÃ´nica Bergamo, da Folha de SÃ£o Paulo, a desembargadora disse que â€“ apesar de publicar um desabafo â€œcomo uma cidadÃ£â€œ â€“ ela apagou a sua publicaÃ§Ã£o e disse explicou que apenas comentou o â€œque ouviu de uma amigaâ€ e que nÃ£o conhecia a vereadora atÃ© saber da sua morte!

NÃ£o encontramos nenhuma notÃ­cia a respeito de exoneraÃ§Ãµes determinadas pela vereadora â€œrecentementeâ€ (e nem tÃ£o recentemente).

Essas afirmaÃ§Ãµes feitas contra a vereadora morta a tiros no Rio de Janeiro surgiram em grupos do WhatsApp e nÃ£o tem nenhuma prova que as sustentem!
title: Marielle Franco foi esposa do Marcinho VP? Era do Comando Vermelho? | E-farsas.com â€“ Desvendando farsas da web desde 2002!

content:
Two students who survived last monthâ€™s high school shooting in Parkland, Fla., said Monday that the leadership of the National Rifle Association (NRA) has â€œbasically threatenedâ€ them since they started speaking out about gun violence.

â€œI think it just goes to prove exactly what they are. I donâ€™t think NRA members are bad people at all. I think theyâ€™re responsible gun owners that want to become politically active and make their voices heard in this democracy,â€ David Hogg told CBS News.

â€œI think the problem comes in when itâ€™s people at the top of this organization that donâ€™t listen to their constituents, and continue to scare people into buying more guns, creating more violence so they can scare more people and sell more guns,â€ he added.

Hogg and classmate Emma GonzÃ¡lez appeared on CBS News on Monday to talk about their efforts to promote stricter gun laws and prevent school shootings.

When asked if the NRA has reached out to the Parkland students in the month since they rallied to stop school shootings, Hogg said the way theyâ€™ve reached out â€œis basically threatening us.â€

â€œTheyâ€™ve been instigating things,â€Â GonzÃ¡lez added. â€œAnd then we reply, they shy away. Like they can dish it out, but they canâ€™t take it.â€

The NRA hasnâ€™t publicly criticized the Parkland students since the shooting, but during last weekâ€™s national day of school walkouts to protest gun violence, the organization shared a photo of a rifle with the caption â€œIâ€™ll control my own guns, thank you.â€

Hogg, GonzÃ¡lez and other Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School students have been at the forefront of the discussion about gun violence following the Feb. 14 shooting at the high school that left 17 people dead.

Since then,Â some lawmakers have expressed support for various legislation, including stronger background checks, an increased age limit on buying rifles and a ban on bump stocks.

So far, Congress has not passed any legislation. The Trump administration earlier this month unveiled a series of proposalsÂ on school safety and gun restrictions, including a push for states to provide firearms training for school staff members.

The proposal did not include any action on guns, but established a committee to assess best practices for preventing school shootings.
title: Parkland students: NRA has been 'basically threatening us'

Black boys raised in America, even those who belong to privileged backgrounds, still earn less in adulthood than white boys with similar backgrounds, concludes a study led by researchers at Stanford, Harvard and the Census Bureau.

content:
The scene near an explosion in Austin.

Three package bombs have gone off in Austin, Texas, in the past two weeks, and they appear to have targeted members of prominent black families, the president of the local NAACP told NBC News Wednesday.

The families of Stephen House, who was killed on March 2, and Draylen Mason, who was killed on Monday, have known each other for a long time â€œand go to the same church,â€ according to Nelson Linder. The Austin NAACP president said that a third bomb, which injured 75-year-old Esperanza Herrera, may have been intended for â€œanother person who might be connected to the House and Mason families.â€

Though the Austin police agree that the bombings are related, they havenâ€™t suggested a motive. They also havenâ€™t said whether they think the victims were personally targeted. But interim Austin police chief Brian Manley did tell reporters this week that theyâ€™re not ruling out the possibly â€œthat hate crime is at the core of this.â€

Mason, 17, was a musician who was set to enroll at the University of Texas Butler School of Music. His grandmother LaVonne Mason is a co-founder of the Austin Area Urban League. House, 39, was a father and founder of his own money-management firm. His stepfather, Freddie Dixon, who is close with Masonâ€™s grandparents, was the longtime pastor at Wesley United Methodist Church, a historic black church that was founded by newly freed slaves.

Dixon told the Washington Post that he doesnâ€™t think the victimsâ€™ history is a coincidence. â€œSomebodyâ€™s done their homework on both of us, and they knew what they were doing,â€ he said. â€œMy diagnosis: Number one, I think itâ€™s a hate crime. Number two, somebodyâ€™s got some kind of vendetta here.â€

Investigators have begun looking into the connection between the Mason and House families, attempting to see if the victimsâ€™ relationships to â€œprominent members of Austinâ€™s African-American communityâ€ is related to the bombings, the Austin American-Statesman reported on Wednesday.

As for the third bomb, police have a theory that it was meant for a woman who is not related to the Mason family, but shares their last name.

The bombs themselves provide some clue as to who may have delivered them. According to ABC News, the explosives â€œdisplayed a level of sophistication, indicating that the bomb-maker or bomb-makers were highly skilled.â€

The devices were set up to be detonated by motion like shaking or jostling, which is why they exploded when they were picked up. The devices also had some sort of safety switch, which enabled the bomber to move the devices without blowing themselves up, the sources briefed on the investigation told ABC News.

As police continue their probe into the bombings, a sense of unease has come over the city as Austinites prepare for another potential bombing. And they remain vigilant. Since Monday, there have been nearly 500 reports of suspicious packages in the city. None of them have contained explosives.

Austin Bombs Appear to Be Targeting Prominent Black Families
title: Austin Bombs Appear to Be Targeting Prominent Black Families

Jim Carrey likes to paint. He also likes to paint caricatures of people from the Trump administration. This one is a pretty good likeness, and didn't need a nametag.

And of course, the kids at Fox & Friends didn't like it one bit.

The appalling portrait Jim Carrey posted Saturday is just the latest lewd artwork the 56-year-old star has released of late, many of them assailing Republican lawmakers and members of President Donald Trumpâ€™s administration.

Jim Carrey faced swift backlash Sunday after the actor tweeted a painting that apparently showed White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders in a terrifyingly garish light.

â€œThis is the portrait of a so-called Christian whose only purpose in life is to lie for the wicked. Monstrous!â€ Carrey wrote in his tweet accompanying the portrait Saturday.

Though Carrey didnâ€™t mention Sanders by name, many Twitter users knew right away who it was, The Wrap reported.
title: Jim Carrey Slammed By Fox News For 'Disgraceful,' Garish Portrait Of Sarah Sanders

Repito: mesmo as mulheres mais independentes, esclarecidas, com mil livros na cabeÃ§a e na cabeceira, carreira e contas bancÃ¡rias sÃ³lidas, mesmo essas nÃ£o estÃ£o livres disso. Ã‰ algo que estÃ¡ muito entranhado em nossas construÃ§Ãµes.NÃ£o estou falando que todos os homens sÃ£o monstros e nem que devemos fugir deles e viver solteiras para sempre. Amar Ã© bom, relacionamentos podem ser saudÃ¡veis, ainda que complicados, mas temos que estar atentas a essa construÃ§Ã£o de amor romÃ¢ntico que nos anula. Na verdade, de onde vejo, acho que muitos deles sÃ£o vÃ­timas de uma construÃ§Ã£o de masculinidade tÃ³xica que execra o feminino e Ã© calcada em violÃªncia e dominaÃ§Ã£o. NÃ£o sabem sequer nomear seus sentimentos e viram uns deficientes emocionais, que nÃ£o sabem lidar com os sentimentos sem ser de formas violentas. PorÃ©m, mesmo eles sendo vÃ­timas dessa masculinidade, quem paga o preÃ§o alto somos nÃ³s, mulheres.E Ã© sÃ³ conversando entre nÃ³s que isso pode mudar. Eles precisam conversar entre eles tambÃ©m. NÃ³s com eles, se eles ouvirem, claro; eles entre eles; e, sobretudo, nÃ³s entre nÃ³s, unidas, se julgamentos e podendo nÃ£o sentir vergonha das fragilidades que temos. Se nÃ£o formos juntas, nÃ£o vamos a lugar algum.

Clara Averbuck Ã© escritora, tem sete livros publicados e jÃ¡ teve a obra adaptada para cinema e teatro. JÃ¡ escreveu para inÃºmeros sites, revistas e jornais e hoje Ã© uma das editoras do site Lugar de Mulher, criado em 2014 e que foi um dos principais agentes a fomentar o debate sobre as questÃµes de gÃªnero no Brasil.

.-Organizaciones sociales y polÃ­ticas dominicanas condenaron enÃ©rgicamente lasÂ desarrolladas contra la migraciÃ³n haitiana en el paÃ­s, como estÃ¡ ocurriendo actualmente en Pedernales donde personas desaprensivas estÃ¡n dando 24 horas a losÂ haitianosÂ residentes allÃ­, luego que una pareja dominicana fuera presuntamente asesinada porÂ haitianos, hecho que debiÃ³ ser inmediatamente aclarado por las autoridades dominicanas, apresando a los culpables del crimen y sometiÃ©ndolos a la justicia para dispensarle el castigo que establecen las leyes.

Tal negligencia tampoco justifica acciones contra inocentes ni hechos reprochables de barbarismo contra la poblaciÃ³n migrante, los cuales presentan una muy mala imagen de la RepÃºblica Dominicana, nacional e internacionalmente.

SeÃ±alan, cÃ³mo losÂ migrantesÂ no llegan solos al paÃ­s e identifican la existencia de redes de trÃ¡fico de personas â€œsin papelesâ€ (haitianosÂ y asiÃ¡ticos) a travÃ©s de la frontera con HaitÃ­, acciones promovidas por elites empresariales para aprovecharse de laÂ mano de obraÂ barataÂ y desprovista de seguridad social, todo lo cual ocurre sin que el Gobierno Dominicano tome medidas efectivas para impedirlo.

â€œEl hecho de que algÃºn haitiano o de cualquier otra nacionalidad cometa actos criminales de violaciÃ³n a las leyes, no debe ser generalizado en contra de todos losÂ migrantes, como es el caso que tratamos. Lo procedente es apresar las personas responsables de los crÃ­menes, someter los violadores frente a las instancias de justicia, pues nunca puede justificarse la violencia ni poner en peligro las vidas y la convivencia de hombres, mujeres y niÃ±osÂ migrantesÂ que desarrollan sus actividades de manera pacÃ­fica y en el marco de las leyesâ€, indicaron.

SeÃ±alan las organizaciones dominicanas que no solo buena parte del pueblo haitiano es migrante, sino tambiÃ©n casi el 20% de la poblaciÃ³n dominicana reside en el exterior desarrollan sus actividades laborales, contribuyendo con sus divisas al sostenimiento econÃ³mico del paÃ­s y de sus familias. Esa es la vida de losÂ migrantesÂ en cualquier paÃ­s.

Â¿Por quÃ© promover la confrontaciÃ³n y la discriminaciÃ³n de pobres contra pobres y entre pueblosÂ migrantes? Â¿CuÃ¡les objetivos se buscan tras esta campaÃ±a y promociÃ³n?, son preguntas que se hacen las instituciones.

â€œActualmente ha conmocionado a EspaÃ±a el involucramiento de una dominicana en el asesinato de un hijo de su novio. Â¿QuÃ© dirÃ­amos si ahora se desarrollara en ese paÃ­s y otros de Europa una campaÃ±a de odio contra toda la comunidad dominicana que nada tiene que ver con esos hechos? RechazarÃ­amos y denunciarÃ­amos tales hipotÃ©ticos hechos. En igual situaciÃ³n rechazamos el acoso de que estÃ¡ siendo sometida la poblaciÃ³n haitiana en Pedernales, y en cualquier otro punto del paÃ­s.â€

Las organizaciones polÃ­ticas y sociales, seÃ±alan que â€œel patriotismo dominicano no podrÃ¡ jamÃ¡s medirse por el odio a losÂ haitianos, sino en trabajar para que podamos vivir libres, felices, independientes y tranquilos. Son los malos dominicanos quienes trabajan para lo contrario, no losÂ haitianos. â€œ

Las instituciones llaman a que la cuestiÃ³n de la migraciÃ³n haitiana y sus descendientes en el paÃ­s no siga siendo tomada como material de campaÃ±a y disputa polÃ­tica, pues se impone el absoluto respeto a los DDHH consignados en la DeclaraciÃ³n Universal, en las convenciones y Pactos ratificados por el paÃ­s. El Estado Dominicano debe reconocer las violaciones a los derechos ciudadanos producidos por la sentencia 168-13 y el genocidio jurÃ­dico que ha significado para cientos de miles de dominicanos de ascendencia haitiana, a quienes, sin justificaciÃ³n alguna, se les despojÃ³ de su nacionalidad dominicana.

Finalmente, las organizaciones llaman al pueblo a abstenerse de participar en acciones de confrontaciÃ³n con la poblaciÃ³n migrante, a exigir al Estado Dominicano polÃ­ticas migratorias justas y asumir discursos coherentes que cierren el paso al terror contra losÂ migrantes, garantizando que la justicia actÃºe diligentemente, la convivencia pacÃ­fica, un ambiente de seguridad y respeto a los derechos de las personas, evitando asÃ­ que se repitan hechos bochornosos y reprochables como los de Pedernales.

"NÃ³s entendemos que asÂ poderosas forÃ§as armadas e capacidades seguras de defesa, sÃ£o vitais para qualquer Estado soberano, especialmente para a RÃºssia que ocupa um sexto da parte da terra e que Ã© rica em todos os recursos que oferece nosso planeta", destacou.

"Capacidades defensivasÂ â€” sÃ£o a garantia de tudo: de paz e saÃºde", finalizou.

Os submarinos nucleares russos conduziram um exercÃ­cio perto das bases militares norte-americanas com o objetivo de evitar a detecÃ§Ã£o quando chegaram perto da costa dos Estados Unidos, disse um comandante do esquadrÃ£o submarino a um canal de TV militar russo.

Os submarinos nucleares russos conduziram um exercÃ­cio perto das bases militares norte-americanas com o objetivo de evitar a detecÃ§Ã£o quando chegaram perto da costa dos Estados Unidos, disse um comandante do esquadrÃ£o submarino a um canal de TV militar russo.

A deslumbrante revelaÃ§Ã£o foi feita em uma sÃ©rie de TV militar lanÃ§ada no Zvezda ('Estrela'), o organismo de transmissÃ£o do MinistÃ©rio da Defesa russo. O episÃ³dio se concentra em submarinos de ataque nucleares de classe Akula, os Shchuka-B.

De acordo com um oficial de submarino entrevistado pelo canal, o comando da Marinha russa ordenou que se posicionasse na proximidade das bases militares dos EUA durante os exercÃ­cios.

"Esta missÃ£o foi realizada, os submarinos apareceram no local definido no oceano e voltaram para a base", disse ao Zvezda o comandante do esquadrÃ£o submarino, Sergei Starshinov.

Perguntado se os submarinos conseguiram ficar longe do radar durante a missÃ£o, Starshinov respondeu afirmativamente.

"Sim. Este Ã© o nosso objetivoÂ â€” ir e vir sem ser detectado", revelou.

O comandante da Marinha disse que asÂ embarcaÃ§Ãµes russas chegaram "suficientemente perto" das margens americanas, mas nÃ£o violaram asÂ fronteiras marÃ­timas dos EUA, permanecendo em Ã¡guas neutras.

A data e a localizaÃ§Ã£o da missÃ£o secreta nÃ£o foram divulgadas, mas o canal disse que os submarinos nucleares russos "chegaram ao litoral dos EUA".

O submarino Shchuka-B foi encomendado para a Marinha SoviÃ©tica em 1986. O submarino de energia nuclear Ã© capaz de lanÃ§ar mÃ­sseis de cruzeiro Kalibr ou Granat, envolvendo alvos subaquÃ¡ticos com seus torpedos de 553mm e podendo ficar submersos por atÃ© 100 dias, de acordo com fontes abertas.

Tal como acontece com muitos submarinos nucleares russos, asÂ informaÃ§Ãµes de seu status, bem como asÂ atualizaÃ§Ãµes atuais e passadas, sÃ£o escassas. Entende-se que vÃ¡rios submarinos desta classe estÃ£o sendo operados pela Marinha russa ou estÃ£o passando por modernizaÃ§Ã£o. Um submarino Shchuka-B foi arrendado para a Ãndia, onde entrou no serviÃ§o sob o nome INS Chakra. Confira primeiro VÃDEO do interior do submarino russo K-335 Gepard

Em 2016, um alto funcionÃ¡rio da Marinha dos EUA queixou-se de que os militares nÃ£o podem garantir a plena consciÃªncia das atualizaÃ§Ãµes de submarinos russos que estavam no nÃ­vel nÃ£o visto desde a Guerra Fria.

"Os submarinos que estamos vendo sÃ£o muito mais sigilosos", disse Ã  CNN o almirante Mark Ferguson, comandante das ForÃ§as Navais dos EUA na Europa na Ã©poca. Os russos "tÃªm sistemas de armas mais avanÃ§ados, sistemas de mÃ­sseis que podem atacar a terra em longas distÃ¢ncias", e suas capacidades operacionais estavam melhorando "Ã  medida que vÃ£o mais longe das Ã¡guas locais".
title: Submarinos russos foram Ã  costa dos EUA sem serem detectados, diz militar russo - Sputnik Brasil

content:
O empresÃ¡rio Ricardo Douche fez o seguinte comentÃ¡rio em uma postagem que homenageava a vereadora Marielle Franco: â€œVai defender bandido, dÃ¡ nisso! Bem feito. Direitos humanos para humanos direitos.â€

Ricardo costuma fazer isso o dia inteiro. â€œTenho muito tempo livre porque aposto em Bitcoin e outras criptomoedas, Ã© o meu negÃ³cioâ€, disse em entrevista exclusiva.

Ricardo Ã© um duro crÃ­tico dos direitos humanos. Mas nÃ£o sabia ao certo do que falava. Quando descobriu que os comentÃ¡rios que faz na internet sÃ³ existem porque vivemos em uma sociedade em que, teoricamente, se respeitam os direitos humanos, ele tomou um susto.

â€œO meu direito de falar o que eu quiser sem ser censurado Ã© um direito humano? Nunca tinha pensado nissoâ€, afirmou.

Ricardo agora pensa em se lanÃ§ar candidato a deputado nas prÃ³ximas eleiÃ§Ãµes. â€œVou usar meu direito de me expressar contra os direitos humanos no palanque. Eu acho que jÃ¡ estÃ¡ bem do jeito que estÃ¡, nÃ£o precisamos dar direitos para mais gente. Eu penso em ser a Ãºltima pessoa beneficiada por esses direitos. O resto agora Ã© bandidoâ€, disse.

A Ãºltima pesquisa mostrou que Ricardo seria eleito com 100 mil votos de sua cidade com 200 mil habitantes.
title: CrÃ­tico de direitos humanos agradece aos direitos humanos por poder criticar defensores dos direitos humanos

content:
South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster (R) is disgusted that thousands of students are protesting gun violence around the nation and described kids walking out of classrooms as â€œshameful.â€

McMaster made his comments on the stateâ€™s public television network ETV on Wednesday and speculated that the students were merely â€œbeing used as a tool by a left-wing group to further their own agenda,â€ even though he offered no evidence of that claim.

â€œIt sounds like a protest to me. Itâ€™s not a memorial, itâ€™s certainly not a prayer service, itâ€™s a political statement by a left-wing group and itâ€™s shameful,â€ McMaster said.

McMaster then suggested that students pray instead of protesting as if God would solve all their problems, not legislation from Congress, or new gun control laws.

Watch some of his comments below:

Contrary to the governorâ€™s comments, the nationwide walkout was actually organized by student survivors of theÂ Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School shooting that killed 17 of their own.

One of those students, David Hogg, who has appeared in the media numerous times since that fateful day, responded to the governor:

â€œThose future voters will not reelect you and outlive you too,â€ Hogg tweeted. He then added: â€œcanâ€™t wait to see what the history books our generation writes will have to say about people like you.â€

Regardless of this one governorâ€™s comments, the message thousands of students sent was â€œEnough is enough.â€ This is the new generation. They may not be able to vote yet, but they will one day. And, you better believe that theyâ€™re not betting on prayer to solve the issue surrounding guns.
title: GOP Governor Attacks Students Protesting Guns, Says They Need To â€˜Prayâ€™ Instead

A Prefeitura de SÃ£o Paulo anunciou que irÃ¡ reestruturar o sistema de saÃºde na cidade. A principal mudanÃ§a serÃ¡ o fechamento de 108 AssistÃªncias MÃ©dicas Ambulatoriais (AMAs), que serÃ£o absorvidas pelas Unidades BÃ¡sicas de SaÃºde (UBSs). A diferenÃ§a entre os dois tipos de estabelecimentos Ã© que as AMAs sÃ£o unidades de pronto atendimento para casos de baixa complexidade, enquanto as UBSs sÃ£o centros mÃ©dicos com consultas agendadas.

De acordo com o secretÃ¡rio de SaÃºde da atual gestÃ£o, Wilson Pollara, 108 AMAs se transformarÃ£o em 63 UBSs, 19 Unidades de Pronto Atendimento (UPAs) e 26 em ambulatÃ³rios de especialidades. â€œO atendimento serÃ¡ exatamente igual, mas a pessoa nÃ£o serÃ¡ atendida por um plantonista que irÃ¡ vÃª-la de vez em quando e sim pelo mÃ©dico de famÃ­lia delaâ€, diz. â€œSe a pessoa precisar de um atendimento de emergÃªncia ela poderÃ¡ ir na AMA de 24 horas que se transformarÃ¡ em uma UPA.â€

O anÃºncio vem gerando manifestaÃ§Ã£o de parte da populaÃ§Ã£o que teme a superlotaÃ§Ã£o das UBSs e dos prontos socorros de hospitais. â€œA melhora do sistema de saÃºde precisa ser discutida. Mas a mudanÃ§a nÃ£o pode ser realizada da noite para o dia porque jÃ¡ se gerou uma demanda pelo serviÃ§o existenteâ€, afirma MarÃ­lia Louvison, professora da Faculdade de SaÃºde PÃºblica da Universidade de SÃ£o Paulo (USP), especialista em regulaÃ§Ã£o do Sistema Ãšnico de SaÃºde.

Para MarÃ­lia, as Unidades BÃ¡sicas de SaÃºde foram criadas, inicialmente, para realizar atendimentos emergenciais e tambÃ©m agendados. Com o aumento da demanda, as gestÃµes optaram por transferir o pronto atendimento Ã s AMAs. â€œPara que tudo seja incorporado pelas UBSs, Ã© preciso que seja realizada uma anÃ¡lise de demandaâ€, diz ela. â€œTambÃ©m nÃ£o se pode esperar que profissionais habilitados para atender em AMAs sejam simplesmente aproveitados em unidades bÃ¡sicas.â€

â€œA populaÃ§Ã£o se queixava que as UBSs sÃ³ atendiam com hora marcada e nÃ£o tinham procedimentos simplesâ€, diz Pollara. Para atender esse tipo de necessidade, foram criadas as AMAs. Com a atual mudanÃ§a, diz o secretÃ¡rio, o mÃ©dico da famÃ­lia realizarÃ¡ esse tipo de consulta.

UBS na zona sul de SÃ£o Paulo Ã© interditada pela Defesa Civil

Incorporar demandas instantÃ¢neas Ã s Unidades BÃ¡sicas de SaÃºde, sem que elas estejam preparadas para dar respostas emergenciais Ã  populaÃ§Ã£o, explica MarÃ­lia, pode criar um risco de desassistÃªncia. â€œSeria mais prudente fazer um experimento local, em alguns territÃ³rios de forma piloto.â€

A ideia da reestruturaÃ§Ã£o Ã© que as famÃ­lias passem a ser atendidas por mÃ©dicos generalistas. Esses profissionais, por sua vez, deverÃ£o os pacientes e encaminhÃ¡-los para especialistas.

Segundo o secretÃ¡rio de saÃºde, as AMAs sÃ£o superlotados porque nÃ£o se consegue dimensionar quem busca esse tipo de atendimento. â€œTem horas que o espaÃ§o fica lotado porque muita gente vai no mesmo horÃ¡rioâ€, afirma. â€œO mÃ©dico da famÃ­lia atende entre 3,5 mil a 4 mil pessoas. Ele tem condiÃ§Ãµes de atender essa populaÃ§Ã£o de forma mais adequada.â€

Hoje, um mÃ©dico das AMAs realiza oito consultas por hora. Na UBS, segundo o Pollara, o profissional realizaria entre trÃªs e quatro atendimentos. â€œNÃ£o existe organizaÃ§Ã£o, o atendimento Ã© falho. NÃ£o hÃ¡ o mÃ­nimo direcionamentoâ€, diz o secretÃ¡rio. Exemplo citado pelo secretÃ¡rio Ã© o caso de um pediatra que serÃ¡ transferido por ter a agenda subutilizada. "Ele possui apenas 40% da agenda ocupada com casos de pesagens e medida de crianÃ§as. Ã‰ um trabalho que pode ser feito pelo mÃ©dico de famÃ­lia.â€

A previsÃ£o da Secretaria da SaÃºde para evitar a superlotaÃ§Ã£i Ã© de que, atÃ© a metade do ano, sejam contratados 250 mÃ©dicos para o programa â€œMÃ©dico da FamÃ­liaâ€ e mais 200 atÃ© o final do ano. A orientaÃ§Ã£o Ã© que as Unidades de Pronto Atendimento (UPAs) sejam procuradas quando as UBSs estiverem fechadas ou quando a urgÃªncia for de mÃ©dia complexidade.

Para MarÃ­lia, da USP, hÃ¡ hoje uma culturaÂ  no PaÃ­s onde se criou uma demanda e uma necessidade pelo atendimento emergencial. â€œPor isso, as mudanÃ§as terÃ£o de ser muito bem preparadas.â€ De acordo com o secretÃ¡rio, apenas duas AMAs passaram pela mudanÃ§a, a do Jardim TietÃª e Vila Carmosina, zona leste de SÃ£o Paulo.

content: Seven years on in Syria: Nobody seems willing to stop the bloodshed              A Syrian child navigates the rubble of the rebel-held town of Duma in east Ghouta on March 8, 2018. (Hamza al Ajweh / AFP/Getty Images)            Slightly more than four years ago, Stephen Hawking, the famed physicist who died Wednesday, described what was happening in Syria as "an abomination, one that the world is watching coldly from a distance."     It was finally time, he wrote, to say "no more."        Yet more is what has come to Syria, which has become an emblem of man-made misery in a conflict that marked its seventh anniversary Thursday.      The crisis, which began as part of the "Arab Spring" uprisings, disintegrated into a hellish civil war that has killed hundreds of thousands. The United Nations gave up tracking the numbers years ago, though some war monitors say roughly 500,000 people have been killed.        Hundreds of thousands more have been wounded, and more than half the country's prewar population of 22 million has been displaced, igniting a refugee crisis that has hardened anti-immigrant sentiments across Europe. Some of the country's most historic cities and sites have been pummeled into wastelands of jagged masonry and rusted rebar â€” the detritus of lives destroyed in campaigns where siege tactics and indiscriminate attacks have become the norm.      In ways, the conflict has redefined what is permissible in wartime.     It has also become an internecine proxy war that has reshaped alliances and helped reopen the doors to the Cold War era. And it has come at the expense of the people all sides claim to want to protect.     "The Syrian conflict has shown the moral bankruptcy and cowardice of the international community. It has exposed the incompetence of the Security Council and the U. N.," said Fawaz Gerges, a Middle East expert at the London School of Economics, in a phone interview Wednesday.           Syrian government forces deploy in the captured town of Beit Sawa in the east Ghouta region. (AFP/Getty Images)         "Syria now has become a battleground for regional and global powers, who are basically trying to grab as much territory as possible in order to maximize their interest," he said.      Of the latest wave of cease-fires, one, Resolution 2401, was unanimously voted into place by the United Nations Security Council in February. A few days later, it was followed by a daily truce ordered by Russian President Vladimir Putin, the top ally of Syrian President Bashar Assad.     They were broken almost before they began.     In Afrin, a Kurdish-dominated enclave in the country's northwest, Turkish troops working alongside Syrian rebels all but ignored the cease-fire and pressed their campaign (euphemistically called Operation Olive Branch) to dislodge the U.S.-allied militias that Ankara views as a proxy for a Kurdish separatist movement in its own territory. More than 200 people have been killed, according to Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, a pro-opposition monitor based in Britain.     In east Ghouta, a network of suburbs near Damascus and home to an estimated 350,000 people, the weeks-long assault on the rebels there continued unabated despite widespread condemnation by world powers.     The rebel-held enclave has endured the full gamut of the war's horrors. In 2013, it was the site of a deadly sarin gas attack that killed hundreds and the target of a years-long government siege.     But that has been eclipsed by the no-holds barred assault this year that has forced residents to seek shelter underground, where they pack by the hundreds in basements to escape the rain of mortar shells, artillery and bombs. The number of dead surpassed 1,000 people this week, as loyalist troops clawed back chunks of rebel-held areas and uprooted thousands.     Elsewhere in the country, the armies of three countries â€” the U.S., Russia and Turkey â€” and the special forces of a few more share a battleground with hundreds of rebel and militant factions fighting pro-government, Iranian-backed militias.        In between them stands the U.N., "which has been taken hostage" as it scrambles to balance the interests of member nations, said Lakhdar Brahimi, a veteran diplomat and former special envoy to Syria.      "During the Cold War, the U.N. was paralyzed because of the disagreements between the major powers," Brahimi said Wednesday. "As far as I'm concerned we're back with the conditions of the Cold War, and the U.N. finds it more and more difficult to act."     Even when aid is delivered, the U.N. as well as other aid groups are criticized for favoring one side over another, said Ali Zaatari, the U.N.'s humanitarian coordinator for the country.     "We have a problem in that all parties want us, as humanitarians working in Syria, to absorb and accept their view of the conflict in a bid to draw legitimacy."     And the fighting has raged on, said Joshua Landis, director of the University of Oklahoma's Center for Middle East Studies, in full view of the world.     "Syria has engaged a great deal of the world's attention in the last seven years," Landis said. "The problem is that no one really cares about Syria the country, it's that they care about the geographic position of Syria and they want leverage.     "They care about Syria, but not the Syrian people."     For many Syrians, the different sides fade into irrelevance when stacked against the horrific toll of the war.        Displaced children from the Kurdish-majority city of Afrin in northern Syria, which is nearly surrounded by Turkish-led forces (Nazeer al Khatib / AFP/Getty Images)        "We believe that the Ghouta is precious for you," Ward Mardini, a pro-opposition activist in the area, wrote to the rebel commanders in Ghouta on her Facebook page. "But we're tired and the situation demands a realistic solution that stanches the waterfall of blood."     Yet no side seems willing to stop.     Through its Kurdish allies, the U.S. controls about 30% of Syria, which it views as a necessary buffer against an Iranian-led power crescent stretching from Tehran to Beirut. Assad's government, which has shown no interest in negotiations, still vows to reclaim all of Syria.     The biggest winners are perhaps Iran and Russia; their support for Damascus, credited for having kept Assad in power and turning the tide of the war in his favor, means they will lead the charge in a reconstruction bonanza that will require an estimated $250 billion. Iranian and Russian firms have already netted electricity, gas and oil contracts.     But even that has become another battlefield; part of a strategy, Landis said, where "no one is allowed to win."     "That has been the guiding thread over the last seven years," he said.     "No one has cared enough to win, but nobody wants to lose."                    A digest of essential news, insight and analysis from L.A. Times editors.       You are now following this newsletter. See all newsletters.
title: Seven years on in Syria: Nobody seems willing to stop the bloodshed

TambÃ©m hÃ¡ relatos de alagamentos no Abranches e na regiÃ£o do Bosque AlemÃ£o. TambÃ©m um trecho da Rua Mateus Leme, prÃ³ximo ao Shopping Mueller ficou alagada. Nas redes sociais internautas postaram fotos de ruas algadas tambÃ©m nos bairros Boa Vista e Bom Retiro.

No Cabral, uma Ã¡rvore caiu e bloqueou o trÃ¢nsito na Rua Manoel Pedro, prÃ³ximo ao Terminal Cabral. SemÃ¡foros em alerta na Av. Pres. GetÃºlio Vargas e na Av. IguaÃ§u, nos cruzamentos com a Av. Pres. Arthur Bernardes, no Santa QuitÃ©ria.

Bloqueio total foi registrado na Rua IapÃ³ com a Rua Guabirotuba, por causa da chuva. Agentes da Setran orientam o trÃ¢nsito. A chuva forte tambÃ©m chegou a bloquear a Rua Engenheiros RebouÃ§as com a Rua Des. Westphalen. O trecho foi liberado dpeois das 16 horas.

Desde a manhÃ£, chove no Sul-Leste do ParanÃ¡. Algumas localidades jÃ¡ tem um volume elevado de chuva, sÃ£o alguns exemplos (atÃ© o comeÃ§po da tarde): Palmas 36,4 mm, InÃ¡cio Martins 48,4 mm, Praia de Leste 40 mm, Rio Negro 33,2 e Lapa 41,8 mm.

Em Curitiba, segundo o Simepar, foram mais de 57 milÃ­metros de chuva nesta quarta-feira, sendo 44 mm sÃ³ em uma hora. A mÃ©dia histÃ³rica de marÃ§o Ã© de 130 mm.

O resto da semana nÃ£o deve ser diferente, com pancadas fortes, mas isoladas, ao longo da tarde.
title: Temporal provoca o caos em Curitiba. Carros ficam submersos. Veja vÃ­deo - Bem ParanÃ¡

content:
Mais de 17 mil juÃ­zes recebem o benefÃ­cio no paÃ­s, a um custo de R$ 74 milhÃµes por mÃªs; maior gasto Ã© da JustiÃ§a estadual de SÃ£o Paulo

Mais de 17 mil juÃ­zes recebem o benefÃ­cio no paÃ­s, a um custo de R$ 74 milhÃµes por mÃªs; maior gasto Ã© da JustiÃ§a estadual de SÃ£o Paulo

Apenas em janeiro deste ano, o JudiciÃ¡rio brasileiro gastou mais de R$ 74 milhÃµes com auxÃ­lio-moradia para cerca de 17 mil juÃ­zes e desembargadores. Ao final de 2018, o valor total gasto no ano pode ultrapassar os R$ 897 milhÃµes, caso todos esses magistrados mantenham seus benefÃ­cios. O teto para o pagamento do auxÃ­lio-moradia, indenizaÃ§Ã£o estendida para todos os magistrados pelo ministro do STF Luiz Fux em 2014, Ã© de R$ 4.377,73 por mÃªs.

Os dados sÃ£o resultado de um levantamento realizado pela AgÃªncia PÃºblica com base nas informaÃ§Ãµes do Conselho Nacional de JustiÃ§a (CNJ) e dos prÃ³prios tribunais.

A reportagem contabilizou todos os benefÃ­cios pagos por 61 dos 62 tribunais federais e estaduais de JustiÃ§a, Militares e do Trabalho, alÃ©m do CNJ, que paga auxÃ­lio a apenas um magistrado, o juiz auxiliar SÃ©rgio Ricardo de Souza, de R$ 4.158,85. Apenas o Tribunal de JustiÃ§a do Mato Grosso nÃ£o respondeu atÃ© o fechamento desta reportagem. Os tribunais eleitorais, sejam o Superior ou os regionais, ficaram de fora do levantamento porque nÃ£o pagam auxÃ­lio-moradia a seus magistrados. O mesmo ocorre com o Conselho da JustiÃ§a Federal.

O Tribunal de JustiÃ§a de SÃ£o Paulo (TJSP) Ã© o campeÃ£o dos pagamentos entre todos os demais tribunais brasileiros âˆ’ foram mais de R$ 10,3 milhÃµes em auxÃ­lio-moradia apenas em janeiro, quase 14% do total gasto no paÃ­s com esse benefÃ­cio. SÃ£o Paulo gasta mais que o dobro do segundo tribunal mais caro, o de JustiÃ§a de Minas Gerais (TJMG), com R$ 4,4 milhÃµes. Ao final de um ano, o TJSP pode gastar R$ 124,5 milhÃµes apenas com esse benefÃ­cio aos seus magistrados.

De um total de 2.536 juÃ­zes e desembargadores ativos no TJSP, apenas 178 nÃ£o receberam os R$ 4.377,73 do auxÃ­lio-moradia em janeiro, o que representa 7% do total. Contudo, isso nÃ£o significa que esses magistrados nÃ£o tiveram direito a auxÃ­lios: entre esses 178, 165 receberam ao menos R$ 810 de auxÃ­lio-alimentaÃ§Ã£o. Apenas 13 juÃ­zes e desembargadores nÃ£o embolsaram nenhum tipo de indenizaÃ§Ã£o em janeiro.

AlÃ©m disso, o TJSP fez em janeiro dois pagamentos de auxÃ­lio-moradia muito acima do teto do CNJ, de R$ 4.377,73. As juÃ­zas de direito Angela Moreno Pacheco de Rezende Lopes e ClÃ¡udia Vilibor Breda receberam, respectivamente, R$ 31 mil e R$ 30,3 de auxÃ­lio-moradia no mÃªs. Conforme a PÃºblica apurou, esses valores estÃ£o sendo pagos para Angela desde outubro de 2017, totalizando R$ 124 mil; e, para ClÃ¡udia, desde setembro de 2107, uma soma de R$ 150 mil.

A escrevente de ClÃ¡udia, Priscila Barbosa, informou que esse valor Ã© devido Ã  magistrada nÃ£o ter recebido o auxÃ­lio-moradia antes de setembro do ano passado. Segundo a funcionÃ¡ria, os valores retroativos estÃ£o sendo pagos em seis parcelas. O gabinete da juÃ­za Angela informou que a resposta deveria vir da assessoria de imprensa do TJ. Procurada, a assessoria confirmou que as duas magistradas recorreram ao auxÃ­lio-moradia tardiamente e recebem pagamentos retroativos parcelados.

AlÃ©m das duas juÃ­zas, 59 magistrados do tribunal receberam indenizaÃ§Ãµes para mudanÃ§a de residÃªncia, reembolsos para aquisiÃ§Ã£o de softwares e hardwares e livros, ajuda de custo para transporte e indenizaÃ§Ãµes por atuaÃ§Ã£o em ColÃ©gio Recursal. Juntos, eles embolsaram mais de R$ 435 mil apenas em janeiro. Quatro desses pagamentos individuais foram acima de R$ 25 mil. Esse tipo de benefÃ­cio encaixa-se tambÃ©m na categoria de indenizaÃ§Ãµes, assim como o auxÃ­lio-moradia e o alimentaÃ§Ã£o.

Segundo a PÃºblica apurou, ao menos dois outros tribunais tambÃ©m fizeram pagamentos de auxÃ­lio-moradia acima do teto em janeiro. Foram eles o Tribunal de JustiÃ§a do Mato Grosso do Sul, que pagou 212 benefÃ­cios acima dos R$ 4.337; e o de JustiÃ§a de RondÃ´nia, que desembolsou 77 auxÃ­lios acima desse valor.

Procurados pela reportagem, nenhum dos tribunais respondeu porque descumpriram o teto de pagamento do auxÃ­lio.

A maior parte dos auxÃ­lios-moradia sÃ£o pagos pelos Tribunais de JustiÃ§a. Juntos, eles desembolsaram R$ 50,4 milhÃµes em janeiro. Em seguida, vÃªm os Tribunais do Trabalho, com R$ 15,6 milhÃµes. Depois, os Tribunais Regionais Federais, com R$ 8,3 milhÃµes. Por Ãºltimo, os Tribunais Militares, que gastaram R$ 345 mil no mÃªs.

Nenhum ministro do STF recebe auxÃ­lio-moradia atualmente, contudo, a PÃºblica apurou que 36 assessores e chefes de gabinete sÃ£o beneficiÃ¡rios. Os valores foram de R$ 1,1 mil a R$ 5 mil em janeiro. Ao todo, o STF gastou mais de R$ 55 mil auxÃ­lio-moradia com esses funcionÃ¡rios no mÃªs. No ano passado, foram mais de R$ 768 mil apenas com esse benefÃ­cio.

O pagamento do auxÃ­lio-moradia e de outras indenizaÃ§Ãµes, como a ajuda para mudanÃ§a de residÃªncia, nÃ£o Ã© contabilizado no teto dos salÃ¡rios dos servidores pÃºblicos, de R$ 33,7 mil. Somando indenizaÃ§Ãµes como auxÃ­lio-natalidade, prÃ©-escola, saÃºde, alimentaÃ§Ã£o e ajudas de custo, os tribunais brasileiros gastaram mais de R$ 110 milhÃµes em auxÃ­lios com seus magistrados apenas em janeiro.

O pagamento do auxÃ­lio-moradia, antes restrito a ministros dos tribunais superiores e a alguns juÃ­zes estaduais, foi estendido a todos os juÃ­zes federais e, em seguida, aos demais magistrados por decisÃµes do ministro Luiz Fux (STF) em 2014.

A prÃ³pria filha do ministro Fux Ã© uma das magistradas que recebem o benefÃ­cio, segundo os dados do CNJ. Desembargadora do Tribunal de JustiÃ§a do Rio de Janeiro, alÃ©m de receber os R$ 4,3 mil de auxÃ­lio-moradia, Marianna recebeu R$ 1.825 de auxÃ­lio-alimentaÃ§Ã£o em janeiro.

Ainda em 2014, o CNJ regulamentou o auxÃ­lio-moradia, estabelecendo o teto de R$ 4.377,73, baseado no valor pago aos ministros do Supremo. O benefÃ­cio nÃ£o pode ser pago a quem possuir residÃªncia oficial Ã  disposiÃ§Ã£o, mesmo que nÃ£o a utilize. JuÃ­zes ou desembargadores inativos tambÃ©m nÃ£o podem receber o auxÃ­lio. O mesmo vale para quem tem algum benefÃ­cio semelhante de outro Ã³rgÃ£o pÃºblico. Para receberem o auxÃ­lio-moradia, os magistrados precisam requerer ao seu tribunal, indicando a localidade da sua residÃªncia.

Mesmo juÃ­zes que possuem residÃªncia prÃ³pria perto do local onde trabalham recebem o auxÃ­lio-moradia. Segundo reportagem da Folha de S. Paulo, metade dos juÃ­zes que ganham auxÃ­lio-moradia em SÃ£o Paulo tem imÃ³vel prÃ³prio â€“ um deles, o desembargador JosÃ© Antonio de Paula Santos Neto, possui 60 propriedades na cidade. O juiz SÃ©rgio Moro, do Tribunal Regional Federal da 4Âª regiÃ£o (TRF-4), responsÃ¡vel pelo julgamento dos processos da Lava Jato, tambÃ©m recebe o benefÃ­cio, apesar de morar a 3 km do trabalho.

A continuidade ou nÃ£o do auxÃ­lio-moradia pode ser definida no plenÃ¡rio do STF no prÃ³ximo dia 22 de marÃ§o, quando os ministros decidem se mantÃªm as decisÃµes de Fux de quatro anos atrÃ¡s. Como resposta, 1.300 juÃ­zes votantes pertencentes Ã  AssociaÃ§Ã£o dos JuÃ­zes Federais (Ajufe) vÃ£o fazer uma paralisaÃ§Ã£o em protesto contra o fim do auxÃ­lio nesta quinta-feira, dia 15.
title: AuxÃ­lio-moradia de juÃ­zes pode custar quase R$ 900 milhÃµes atÃ© o fim do ano

content: Instante AstronÃ´mico 14-03-2018
title: Instante AstronÃ´mico 14-03-2018

content:
Most Americans in a new poll supportÂ stricterÂ gun regulations, with even a majority of National Rifle Association in the survey backingÂ stiffer background checks.

Sixty-nineÂ percent of NRA members expressedÂ support for comprehensive background checks. A proposal to implementÂ universal background checks would apply toÂ all gun sales, rather than just purchases made at licensed retailers, according to the Giffords Law Center, a gun control advocacy group.

Support for such a measure increases toÂ 78 percent among gun owners who donâ€™t belong to the NRA and to 89 percent for respondents who donâ€™t own a firearm. The poll of 803 American adultsÂ was conducted by Monmouth University from March 2-5, weeks after a highÂ school shooting in Parkland, Florida.

Comprehensive background checks are considerably more popular among gun owners than is a national firearms registry, a policy proposal often raisedÂ after mass shootings. Among those who donâ€™t own guns, 79 percent support a firearms-purchase database, but only half of gun owners back such a proposal. The level of support drops toÂ 31 percent among NRA members.

Although opinion polls indicate supportÂ for some gun control regulations, thereâ€™s been little movement at the federal level to pass new laws. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, has not proposed a timeline for consideration of firearms regulation; last week, Congress turned its attention to an unrelated banking measure.

Many of the changes to firearms policyÂ are instead coming from the retail sector. Walmart Inc., Dickâ€™s Sporting Goods Inc., Kroger Co.Â and L. L. Bean Inc. have all saidÂ they would stop selling firearms to 18- to 20-year-olds in the wake of the Florida shootingÂ last month, in which a 19-year-old gunman was charged with killing 17 people. OrvisÂ Co., an outdoor goods retailer, said it would sell firearms onlyÂ to those under the age of 21 if they have completed a education and safety course. Dickâ€™s also halted the sale of assault-style rifles.

Support for gun control measures is divided along party lines, but background checks drew broad support. The policy has the approval of 91 percent of Democrats, 83 percent of independents and 72 percent of Republicans. The partisan split over a firearms ownership database is more pronounced: Some 84 percent of Democrats favor such a measure, while only 45 percent of Republicans do.

NRA members, in particular, strongly opposed such a registry. Among members of the group, 79 percent expressed concern that a regulation such as increased background checks or a firearms purchase registry could be used to track the activities of Americans.

â€œThere is still a stark political divide driven by special interests who represent about one-third of gun owners,â€ Patrick Murray, director of the independent Monmouth University Polling Institute, said in a statement. â€œThe NRAâ€™s influence in Washington may still be powerful enough to maintain the status quo on national gun policy.â€
title: Most Gun Owners Support Stricter Lawsâ€”Even NRA Members

title: ***NEW VIDEO***

content:
Special counsel Robert Mueller's team is asking witnesses pointed questions about whether Donald Trump was aware that Democratic emails had been stolen before that was publicly known, and whether he was involved in their strategic release, according to multiple people familiar with the probe.

Mueller's investigators have asked witnesses whether Trump was aware of plans for WikiLeaks to publish the emails. They have also asked about the relationship between GOP operative Roger Stone and WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, and why Trump took policy positions favorable to Russia.

The line of questioning suggests the special counsel, who is tasked with examining whether there was collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia during the 2016 election, is looking into possible coordination between WikiLeaks and Trump associates in disseminating the emails, which U. S. intelligence officials say were stolen by Russia.

Trump has repeatedly denied any collusion and has described the special counsel's investigation as "illegal" and a "witch hunt."

In one line of questioning, investigators have focused on Trump's public comments in July 2016 asking Russia to find emails that were deleted by his then-opponent Hillary Clinton from a private server she maintained while secretary of state. The comments came at a news conference on July 27, 2016, just days after WikiLeaks began publishing the Democratic National Committee emails. "Russia, if you're listening, I hope you're able to find the 30,000 emails that are missing," Trump said.

Witnesses have been asked whether Trump himself knew then that Clinton's campaign chairman John Podesta, whose emails were released several months later, had already been targeted. They were also asked if Trump was advised to make the statement about Clinton's emails from someone outside his campaign, and if the witnesses had reason to believe Trump tried to coordinate the release of the DNC emails to do the most damage to Clinton, the people familiar with the matter said.

The White House spokesman at the time, Sean Spicer, would later say that then-candidate Trump had been "joking" when he called on Russia to hack his opponent's emails.

"In 2016, the hack of my emails was often treated as a politically interesting event," said Podesta to NBC News via email. "For the record, it was a crime. Glad Mueller is trying to get to the bottom of everyone involved in that crime."

Investigators are also asking questions about Trump's longtime relationship with Stone, the Republican operative, according to witnesses. Investigators have asked about Stone's contacts with WikiLeaks during the campaign and if he's ever met with Assange.

"They wanted to see if there was a scheme. Was Stone working on the side for Trump?" after he officially left the campaign, one person interviewed by the special counsel's office said, adding that it seemed investigators wanted to know, "Was this a big plot?"

Russia stole emails from the DNC and Podesta, according to U. S. intelligence officials, and released batches of them through WikiLeaks starting in July 2016 and up until the election.

Click here to see NBC's interactive Russia timeline

As part of his plea agreement with the special counsel, former Trump foreign policy adviser George Papadopoulos revealed that in a conversation in late April 2016, he was told by a professor with ties to Russian officials that they had "dirt' on Clinton in the form of "thousands of emails." A 10-page memo from Democrats on the House Intelligence Committee released Saturday noted that the Justice Department's October 2016 application for a FISA warrant on another Trump foreign policy adviser, Carter Page, included the fact that Russian agents had previewed their hack and dissemination of stolen emails to Papadopoulos.

Investigators were interested in statements Stone made in the final month of the 2016 campaign that strongly suggested he was aware of information the group had before it became public and when it might be released. In one instance, he wrote on Twitter that "it would soon be Podesta's time in the barrel." Weeks later Podesta's stolen emails were released by WikiLeaks.

As WikiLeaks was strategically publishing stolen emails in the closing months of the campaign, Trump also publicly said he loved the group. He mentioned WikiLeaks 145 times during the last month of the 2016 campaign. In 2017, President Trump's CIA director, Mike Pompeo, would label the group a hostile non-state actor.

Investigators also have shown interest in any connections Stone has to WikiLeaks and Assange, its founder. Stone has said he communicated with Assange and WikiLeaks through an intermediary he described as a journalist.

The Atlantic reported this week that Stone exchanged direct messages on Twitter with WikiLeaks. Rep. Adam Schiff of California, the top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, has said his committee should subpoena Twitter to produce any direct messages "from and between the Twitter handles identified as relevant to the Russia investigation," including WikiLeaks, Assange and Stone. According to Schiff, Twitter has told the committee it won't produce such messages "absent compulsion."

Mueller's team has asked witnesses if Stone ever met with Assange. Stone has denied ever communicating directly with Assange.

Stone served briefly on the Trump campaign in 2015, leaving in August of that year. At the time he said he quit, while the campaign said he was fired.

Investigators have asked witnesses about Stone's time on the campaign and what his relationship was like with Trump after he left.

"How often did they talk? Who really fired him? Was he really fired?" a witness said, describing the line of questioning.

In a statement, Stone said he had "no advance knowledge of the content or source of information published by WikiLeaks."

"I have not been interviewed by the special counsel," wrote Stone. "I never discussed WikiLeaks, Assange or the Hillary disclosures with candidate Trump, before during or after the election. I have no idea what he knew about them, from who or when. I have never met Assange."

Stone appeared before the House Intelligence Committee for four hours last September. In his prepared opening statement, which he also delivered publicly on the InfoWars YouTube channel, Stone denied that he ever engaged "in any illegal activities on behalf of my clients, or the causes which I support." He denied having direct contact with Assange and called any exchanges with Guccifer 2.0, which took credit for hacking the DNC, "innocuous."

And he said his tweet predicting that Podesta would spend time in the "barrel" was in the context of the coverage of the resignation of former Trump campaign chair Paul Manafort, whom he called his "boyhood friend and colleague," over allegations about business activities in Ukraine.

At that same July 2016 news conference where he referenced Clinton's missing emails, candidate Trump said he was open to lifting sanctions on Russia and possibly recognizing its annexation of Crimea in Ukraine. The U. S. and its European allies had sanctioned Russia because of its intervention in Ukraine and annexation of Crimea, which the Obama administration refused to recognize.

Investigators have asked witnesses why Trump took policy positions that were friendly toward Russia and spoke positively about Russian President Vladimir Putin, according to people familiar with the probe.

Investigators have also inquired whether Trump met with Putin before becoming president, including if a meeting took place during Trump's 2013 visit to Moscow for his Miss Universe pageant. Trump has given conflicting responses on when he first met Putin.

At least one witness was asked about Trump's business interests in Moscow and surmised afterward that the special counsel investigation may be focused on business dealings that took place during the campaign.

Witnesses also have been asked about Stone's connections to Manafort.

At least one witness has been asked about Trump aide Dan Scavino, specifically about any involvement he may have had in the campaign's data operation. Scavino currently runs the White House's social media operations and is one of Trump's closest aides.

NBC News reached out to Trump's legal team and the White House. The White House declined to comment on Scavino "out of respect for the Office of Special Counsel and its process. ... The White House remains fully cooperative with the Office of Special Counsel and we look forward to [the investigation's] prompt conclusion."

John Dowd, the presidentâ€™s outside attorney, told NBC News, "We do not discuss our knowledge of or communications with the special counsel."
title: Mueller asking what Trump knew about hacked emails

BeneficiÃ¡ria do Bolsa FamÃ­lia em fila de casa lotÃ©rica, em Nova IguaÃ§u

BRASÃLIA â€” O governo pretende mexer no programa Bolsa FamÃ­lia para introduzir o conceito de dignidade, segundo uma fonte a par do assunto. TambÃ©m se cogitou trocar o nome por "Bolsa Dignidade", mas existem dÃºvidas se isso Ã© possÃ­vel e avalia-se o risco de eventual repercussÃ£o negativa da medida em ano eleitoral. TambÃ©m estÃ¡ em discussÃ£o a possibilidade de pagar um adicional de R$ 20 para os beneficiÃ¡rios que realizarem trabalho voluntÃ¡rio.

Outra proposta em anÃ¡lise Ã© reajustar o Bolsa FamÃ­lia para repor a inflaÃ§Ã£o (que fechou 2017 em 2,95%) e mais parte do aumento do botijÃ£o de gÃ¡s como uma forma de compensar o impacto da alta do produto no orÃ§amento das famÃ­lias mais pobres. O Ãºltimo aumento do Bolsa ocorreu em meados de 2016, de 12,5%.

O presidente Michel Temer pediu ao ministro do Desenvolvimento Social, Osmar Terra, para apresentar uma proposta ainda em marÃ§o, a fim de o aumento possa ser pago dentro de um mÃªs. O ministro quer anunciar a medida antes de deixar o cargo para disputar uma cadeira na CÃ¢mara dos Deputados.

On a seemingly daily basis, we see attacks against the intellectual culture of the academic humanities, which, since the 1960s, have opened up spaces for leftists to develop critical theories of all kinds. Attacks from supposedly liberal professors and centrist op-ed columnists, from well-funded conservative think tanks and white supremacists on college campus tours. All rail against the evils of feminism, post-modernism, and something called â€œneo-Marxismâ€ with outsized agitation.

For students and professors, the onslaughts are exhausting, and not only because they have very real, often dangerous, consequences, but because they all attack the same straw men (or â€œstraw peopleâ€) and refuse to engage with academic thought on its own terms. Rarely, in the exasperating proliferation of cranky, cherry-picked anti-academia op-eds do we encounter people actually reading and grappling with the ideas of their supposed ideological nemeses.

Were non-academic critics to take academic work seriously, they might notice that debates over â€œpolitical correctness,â€ "thought policing," "identity politics," etc. have been going on for thirty years now, and among left intellectuals themselves. Contrary to what many seem to think, criticism of liberal ideology has not been banned in the academy. It is absolutely the case that the humanities have become increasingly hostile to irresponsible opinions that dehumanize people, like emergency room doctors become hostile to drunk driving. But it does not follow therefore that one cannot disagree with the establishment, as though the University system were still beholden to the Vatican.

Understanding this requires work many people are unwilling to do, either because theyâ€™re busy and distracted or, perhaps more often, because they have other, bad faith agendas. Should one decide to survey the philosophical debates on the left, however, an excellent place to start would be Radical Philosophy, which describes itself as a â€œUK-based journal of socialist and feminist philosophy.â€ Founded in 1972, in response to â€œthe widely-felt discontent with the sterility of academic philosophy at the time,â€ the journal was itself an act of protest against the culture of academia.

Radical PhilosophyÂ has published essays and interviews with nearly all of the big names in academic philosophy on the leftâ€”from Marxists, to post-structuralists, to post-colonialists, to phenomenologists, to critical theorists, to Lacanians, to queer theorists, to radical theologians, to the pragmatist Richard Rorty, who made arguments for national pride and made several critiques of critical theory as an illiberal enterprise. The full range of radical critical theory over the past 45 years appears here, as well as contrarian responses from philosophers on the left.

Rorty was hardly the only one in the journalâ€™s pages to critique certain prominent trends. Sociologists Pierre Bourdieu and Loic Wacquant launched a 2001 protest against what they called â€œa strange Newspeak,â€ or â€œNewLiberalSpeakâ€ that included words like â€œglobalization,â€ â€œgovernance,â€ â€œemployability,â€ â€œunderclass,â€ â€œcommunitarianism,â€ â€œmulticulturalismâ€ and â€œtheir so-called postmodern cousins.â€ Bourdieu and Wacquant argued that this discourse obscures â€œthe terms â€˜capitalism,â€™ â€˜class,â€™ â€˜exploitation,â€™ â€˜domination,â€™ and â€˜inequality,â€™â€ as part of a â€œneoliberal revolution,â€ that intends to â€œremake the world by sweeping away the social and economic conquests of a century of social struggles.â€

One can also find in the pages of Radical Philosophy philosopher Alain Badiouâ€™s 2005 critique of â€œdemocratic materialism,â€ which he identifies as a â€œpostmodernismâ€ that â€œrecognizes the objective existence of bodies alone. Who would ever speak today, other than to conform to a certain rhetoric? Of the separability of our immortal soul?â€ Badiou identifies the ideal of maximum tolerance as one that also, paradoxically, â€œguides us, irresistiblyâ€ to war. But he refuses to counter democratic materialismâ€™s maxim that â€œthere are only bodies and languagesâ€ with what he calls â€œits formal oppositeâ€¦ â€˜aristocratic idealism.â€™â€ Instead, he adds the supplementary phrase, â€œexcept that there are truths.â€

Badiouâ€™s polemic includes an oblique swipe at Stalinism, a critique Michel Foucault makes in more depth in a 1975 interview, in which he approvingly cites phenomenologist Merleau-Pontyâ€™s â€œargument against the Communism of the timeâ€¦ that it has destroyed the dialectic of individual and historyâ€”and hence the possibility of a humanistic society and individual freedom.â€ Foucault made a case for this â€œdialectical relationshipâ€ as that â€œin which the free and open human project consists.â€ In an interview two years later, he talks of prisons as institutions â€œno less perfect than school or barracks or hospitalâ€ for repressing and transforming individuals.

Foucaultâ€™s political philosophy inspired feminist and queer theorist Judith Butler, whose arguments inspired many of todayâ€™s gender theorists, and who is deeply concerned with questions of ethics, morality, and social responsibility. Her Adorno Prize Lecture, published in a 2012 issue, took up Theodor Adornoâ€™s challenge of how it is possible to live a good life in bad circumstances (under fascism, for example)â€”a classical political question that she engages through the work of Orlando Patterson, Hannah Arendt, Ludwig Wittgenstein, and Hegel. Her lecture ends with a discussion of the ethical duty to actively resist and protest an intolerable status quo.

You can now read for free all of these essays and hundreds more at the Radical Philosophy archive, either on the site itself or in downloadable PDFs. The journal, run by an â€˜Editorial Collective,â€ still appears three times a year. The most recent issue features an essay by Lars T. Lih on the Russian Revolution through the lens of Thomas Hobbes, a detailed historical account by Nathan Brown of the term â€œpostmodern,â€ and its inapplicability to the present moment, and an essay by Jamila M. H. Mascat on the problem of Hegelian abstraction.

If nothing else, these essays and many others should upend facile notions of leftist academic philosophy as dominated by â€œpostmodernâ€ denials of truth, morality, freedom, and Enlightenment thought, as doctrinaire Stalinism, or little more than thought policing through dogmatic political correctness. For every argument in the pages of Radical Philosophy that might confirm certain readers' biases, there are dozens more that will challenge their assumptions, bearing out Foucaultâ€™s observation that â€œphilosophy cannot be an endless scrutiny of its own propositions.â€

On the Power of Teaching Philosophy in Prisons

Josh JonesÂ is a writer and musician based in Durham, NC. Follow him atÂ @jdmagness
title: The Entire Archives of Radical Philosophy Go Online: Read Essays by Michel Foucault, Alain Badiou, Judith Butler & More (1972-2018)
